#Text=Prune
#Text=Dill
#Text=Dill is a tender herb that grows rapidly without much help .
#Text=While you can prune it back to shape it , you generally do n't need to .
#Text=However , you can trim it to harvest some of the dill all throughout the growing season to use and store .
#Text=At the end of the growing season , cut the dill back to the ground and save the herbs by drying them .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Cutting and Shaping Dill
#Text=Trim leaves from the top to encourage bushier growth .
#Text=Try to pick leaves near the top of the plant to trim off .
#Text=That will encourage the plant to grow outward rather than upward .
#Text=When you look at a dill plant , you 'll see many tiny stems going off the main branch , each with little fern-like fingers on it .
#Text=Each of these tiny stems is a leaf .
#Text=Pinch off small branches here and there for flavoring your food .
#Text=If you just want a bit of dill for your dinner , you can simply use your fingers to remove a few branches .
#Text=They are soft enough that you should n't have trouble pulling them off this way .
#Text=This does n't hurt the plant as long as your careful not to yank it so much that it pulls out of the ground .
#Text=Prune or harvest all throughout the season .
#Text=Some plants do n't like pruning at certain times of the season .
#Text=However , with dill , you can prune or harvest it any time it is green and growing .
#Text=However , you may want to wait for it to mature before you prune it heavily .
#Text=It usually takes about 8 weeks from to grow from seed to a mature plant .
#Text=Leave at least 2/3 of the plant when pruning .
#Text=When you 're pruning or harvesting , try not to cut more than 1/3 of the plant off .
#Text=You want to leave enough leaves on the plant that it still has a chance to gather the sun it needs .
#Text=If you cut too much , your plant could wither .
#Text=Pinch off flowers to keep the plant from going to seed .
#Text=During the growing season , it 's a good idea to pinch off flowers as they come in .
#Text=That keeps the plant growing .
#Text=If you let the plant go to seed , it will generally die off .
#Text=Pinch the stem where the flower 's branch meets another branch .
#Text=Nip it just above the joint .
#Text=Dill flowers are tiny and yellow .
#Text=They cluster in rings near the top of the plant .
#Text=At the end of the season , you can either harvest the seeds or let the plant reseed itself .
#Text=Reseeding just means you let the plant drop its seeds in the ground so it comes back next year .
#Text=Storing and Using Fresh Dill
#Text=Use your dill as quickly as you can .
#Text=If possible , use your dill within a couple of hours .
#Text=It will have the most flavor in this time period .
#Text=For that reason , it 's best to cut it right before you want to use it in your food .
#Text=Try cutting dill with scissors instead of a knife when preparing it in the kitchen .
#Text=It will be more flavorful .
#Text=Cut branches off the main stem when you 're planning to store dill .
#Text=When looking at the plant , look for shoots going off the main stem at a perpendicular angle .
#Text=Use small shears to cut the shoot about or less above the joint .
#Text=Cutting causes less damage to the plant , so it keeps it from decaying as fast if you 're planning on storing it .
#Text=Store dill in a jar in the refrigerator .
#Text=Add of water to the bottom of a mason jar .
#Text=Snip off the bottom of the stems on the dill , and place the dill stem-side down in the water .
#Text=Cover it with a lid , if possible , and put it in the fridge .
#Text=If a lid wo n't fit over the jar , use a plastic bag and a rubber band .
#Text=Store the herbs for up to 2 weeks .
#Text=Harvesting Dill at the End of the Season
#Text=Spray the dill with water the day before you harvest it .
#Text=To harvest whole dill plants , wait until the plant has flowers but has n't bloomed .
#Text=Spraying the plant the day before you harvest ensures the plant is clear of dirt when you do cut it .
#Text=You do n't want water on the plant the day you harvest , as that can lead to decay .
#Text=Cut dill to the ground at the end of the growing season .
#Text=Dill is an annual , so at the end of the season , you can simply cut it at the base of the stem .
#Text=Use pruning shears to cut off the plant .
#Text=Cut the dill in the morning to ensure the plant has moisture .
#Text=You want the plant to be hydrated it when you cut it .
#Text=If you ca n't cut it in the morning , place the stems in a glass of water like you would flowers .
#Text=Leave them in the water for 2 hours .
#Text=Hang the dill to dry .
#Text=Combine the dill into small bundles , and place rubber bands around them to keep them together .
#Text=Pick an area that 's dark and warm with low humidity .
#Text=Hang the bunches up to dry .
#Text=Do n't make the bundles too tight .
#Text=Loose bundles promote air circulation , discouraging mold growth .
#Text=Leave them for 1-2 weeks .
#Text=They 're ready when the leaves are dry enough to crumble in your hand .
#Text=Crumble the dill into a jar , or store it whole in an airtight container .
#Text=Check the jar after a week for moisture .
#Text=If you see any , take the dill out of the jar and spread it out to dry .
#Text=Save seeds by hanging the plants upside down in a bag .
#Text=Watch for the blooms , and then the seeds .
#Text=Cut the stalk below the flower once the seeds have appeared .
#Text=Do n't wait for them to start dropping off the plant .
#Text=Place the plants in bag , and hang them up .
#Text=The seeds will fall into the bag .
#Text=Quick Summary
